Title:
Botryosphaeria corticola sp. nov. on Quercus species, with
notes and description of Botryosphaeria stevensii and its anamorph
Diplodia mutila.
Abstract:
Botryosphaeria stevensii has frequently been associated
with dieback and canker diseases of oaks, mainly in the Western
Mediterranean area but more rarely in other regions. The species concept
of B. stevensii has been unclear, and it is possible that some
collections were incorrectly identified. A collection of fungal strains
isolated from diseased oak trees and initially identified as B.
stevensii was characterized on the basis of morphology and ITS
nucleotide sequences. Morphology was compared with the type specimens of
Physalospora mutila (= B. stevensii) and its anamorph Diplodia mutila.
It was concluded that the isolates from oaks differed from B. stevensii
in having larger ascospores and conidia as well as different spore
shapes, and represented an as yet undescribed species, which is
described here as B. corticola. Moreover, ITS sequence data separated B.
corticola from all other known species of Botryosphaeria. Amended
descriptions of B. stevensii and its anamorph are provided to
differentiate B. stevensii from B. corticola and to clarify some of the
earlier taxonomic uncertainties.
